Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2007 02:32PM kimf wrote: Hi Kimmie, I had a vertigo episode during treatment and I was throwing up and spinning and throwing up and spinning...it was horrible. I remember Isabella was only 2 at the time and I didn't want to try to lift her out of the crib for fear I would drop her, it is so life-affecting. Anyhoo, valium and anti-vert was the treatment for me, too. Meclizine or something like that was the winner for getting rid of it. I stopped the valium b/c it made me tired and dizzy! Glad the scan was clean. Continue on the antivert and it will resolve within a few days. Good luck Kim

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2009 01:17PM kimf wrote: Debi, I had left side rads to five areas, your same spots plus in the center of my chest. I had 15+ nodes. I did IMRT radiation, which is more targeted and was promised that my heart would not even be touched (it wasn't). I have only the slightest hint of some dead cells at the very tippy top of my left lung. Nothing more, no shortness of breath, no ill effects. I am more than 3 years out after rads and doing just fine. Please keep that appt with the second opinion and ask about IMRT. Good luck

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2010 06:34AM kimf wrote: I had AC, Taxol and a year of Herceptin without a port and using only one arm. My hospital only inserts the port when all arm veins are caput. I lasted throughout all chemo, blood tests, IV's etc without the port. Good luck on the 22nd!
Posts.Title: Our new girl needs some support! Let-It-Be dee1961

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2009 08:32AM kimf wrote: Hi Lou and Mary, I am a patient at MSK and saw my Onc on Monday. We had an indepth discussion on recurrence. I am er/pr negative, her2+, so we were only discussing my situation. Based on her knowledge and studies done at MSK, if I can get to 5 years out from completing chemo, which for me was July '05, then I am nearly clear sailing. Up until 5 years it is touch and go. Still today the hope is that Herceptin long term will have done all it was suppose to do to keep a recurrence from happening, but the study for non-mets patients just isn't old enough to state whether that is the case or not. She said that er/pr positive girls do not necessarily have the 5 year rule as recurrence can occur later, although I'm not suggesting in any way that it will occur at all. Our therapies today are so much more aggressive and successful than the older studies have indicated. Just wanted to share what I learned this week. Best wishes, Kim
Posts.Title: MSKvsNCI Study/Stats lrsreyes YATCOMW

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2011 01:10PM kimf wrote: I'm 7 years out NED, stage IIIC her2+  No PET's CT's nada. She does do tumor markers.  I have a breast mri and mammo every year. So far doing great. If I develop any symptoms, the PET and CT will come into play, otherwise not necessary according to my Onc.

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2012 01:37AM kimf wrote: My Onc told me to go live my life and consider myself cured, too. She said that once a year come back for mammo, mri and bloodwork, otherwise, just live! It was scary at fiirst, but I'm enjoying it, truthfully. I still listen to my body and check for lumps etc, but will not worry about another cancer or recurrence unless its staring me in the face. No need to be a Debbie Downer when you can enjoy each day of survival. It will be what it wll be when the time comes if ever. In the meantime, eat well, exercise and enjoy!

Posts.Content: May 4, 2009 07:01AM kimf wrote: Ativan is my nightly regime. Without it I don't sleep at all (last night as an example). A lot of people are against using this drug long term, but I have absolutely no inhibitions with it...it works!  And after bc and thyroid ca, I really don't care if I am addicted to a sleep aid.  Sleep is incredibly important in staying healthy! I did try Lexapro and it wasn't right for me. I am on Wellbutrin and have had no s/e from it. Lexapro made my psycho Mom but it has been used successfully by many on these boards. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Sleep help please roxy42 Fire44fly

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2009 12:57PM kimf wrote: Hi Apple, Glad that you formally joined this brave group of girls. I was dx'd in 2004 and haven't been around much recently, but wanted to say hello and echo Nancy's sentiment that unless the cancer has progressed to the bone or distant organ, it is still stage III. If the PET shows metastasis, there are still plenty of options, very successful ones I might add. You sound like you've got your head in the right place. This time, however, I think you should ask all the questions you can come up with regarding your type of cancer. Hormonals and Herceptin are readily available if you are either er/pr pos or Her2 pos. Go after it agressively friend...you will have all of us cheering you on.  Let us know how your test comes back. Kimf

Posts.Title: Happy Holidays Bugs Octobergirl

Posts.Content: kimf wrote: Just checking in to say hi. Been so busy lately that I haven't had time to check everyone's posts. I'm with you in spirit all the time my friends...even if I'm popping in infrequently. Saw my Endocrinologist yesterday. Everything is looking fine with my Synthroid & seems a complete cure to the thyroid cancer. I didn't expect anything suspicious. It was just a follow up. Sometimes sucks going 3 1/2 hours each way to New York for just a follow up...but I'll never regret going to Sloan for all this cancer crap. They've been the best to me. The boys started baseball this month, so things get busy really quickly for me. Both boys play on a different team and on a different level, so there is either practice or a game almost every night. We live at that darn ballpark until June! But, they love it and I love them, so we stick it out. Bella has her dance recital in June, too. OMG, the 3 & 4 year olds are just so precious up there doing their tap and ballet. I just well up thinking about it. She was only 2 when I was dx'd and I worried to death about not seeing her first recital...now I get to see her second and planning on seeing all the rest, too! Did the Elizabeth Edwards recurrence hit you guys as hard as it hit me? Damn disease. I hate it. Fill me in on what is going on! Kim Kimf Dx 12/16/2004, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 3, 15/23 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2007 08:15AM - edited Oct 5, 2007 08:15AM by kimf Yesterday was okay with my FIL. He had another CT scan (they wanted their own..you know how hospitals are). They are doing the biopsy this morning. It will be a fine needle biopsy - hoping for the pathology by Monday. On Monday they will put the stint in, too. I've been reading a lot and trying to learn as much as I can as quickly as possible to help them through this. They are not great with computers. I'm printing articles from Memorial Sloan Kettering and Hopkins hoping the information is valid. Generally, if the tumor is inoperable, it might not go well. Yesterday, the surgeon told my FIL it was inoperable. So... you know.  I had to tell him yesterday that they found a spot on his liver that might be a metastasis. He didn't know that. Do you think that is possible? They didn't tell him? Or that he just didn't understand it when the Onc explained the MRI results? This is frustrating.  I'll let you know more when I know. Thanks for the prayers. Kim
Posts.Title: Hey girls kimf nguyenthang102

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2007 04:25PM - edited Oct 7, 2007 04:25PM by kimf Thanks VV, it is hard being the dil and not knowing how much I should say, or not say. Linda, I will be in touch! You are going to be an excellent source of info, I can tell. Thank you for your thoughts! I am very outspoken and usually try to say it politically correct, but still, this is hard. The latest....they did the biopsy on Friday and sent my fil home. He wasn't resting well in the hospital so they sent him home to await the biopsy results. I thought they would do the stint by Monday, but they said they are waiting for the biopsy results. Why? The stint is necessary no matter what, so why wait? I'm worried they will determine that it has progressed too far already and that they aren't going to insert the stint. Instead, they are suggesting draining the fluid to relieve him a bit. I think that is crap. They should be putting the stint in for long term relief. His care coordinator happens to be a family friend, the only one at the cancer center, so she will be honest with me, I believe. My MIL doesn't get it. She said, "if it was serious" a few times and I wanted to strangle her. WTF does it have to be to be classified as serious to her???? Okay, one piece of good news....most of you know I'm a huge Springsteen fan. I've seen him dozens of times. Friday night, Pete, my brother Dave, and I went into Philly and saw him, which was great. But even better, we went back in town last night for night #2 in Philly and brought my boys!  I was so psyched! They are fans by default..they haven't had the chance to not be! They had a blast. I was tickled to be able to share the night with them. Now for the last bit of potentially bad news. God, does it ever end? My brother Dave...who is one of my best friends. We have the same group of friends from high school, we went to college together, we lived together after college...you get the picture. Anyway...he has had two surgeries for diverticulitis and was told he wouldn't have any more problems after the last surgery. Two weeks ago he started having pain, so went for a CT scan immediately. Friday before the concert he went to see is PCP who told him his colon looks clean, but there is a 5 mm "something" on his left lung. Can you freakin believe that? Now he has to have another CT and a chest Xray. He was never a smoke, thank God, so we are really, really hopeful this is nothing. If it is something, I am going to completely lose it. This is just too much. I'm overwhelmed. And I don't like being overwhelmed. Not at all. I'm off to visit my fil and have some homemade italian pasta for dinner. Be envious! The one thing my mil can do well is cook some mean spaghetti! Thanks for letting me vent. Kim

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2007 04:30PM kimf wrote: Hi friends, Yeah Bugs for thinking about recon. I never regretted my tram, but I wish I had the guts to have my other breast lifted to match. One day.... I mentioned several times that my father in law is really sick. The doctors are thinking he has cholangiocarcinoma, i.e.: bile duct cancer, but they have been unsuccessful in obtaining a biopsy. He did have a drainage tube inserted to drain the bile that had backing up. It was working and his bilirubin level was reducing, but a few days ago he took a bad turn. He wouldn't eat or drink, wanted to only sleep, didn't communicate well. I walked in yesterday and he looked terrible. I used his blood pressure cuff and tried 4 times to get a reading and it wouldn't pick anything up. I rushed him to the hospital and his bp was 77/45. Turns out, he was so severely dehydrated since he was refusing to eat and drink that he went into renal failure. They've been able to stablize him with IV & antibiotics, but his kidneys have not started working (24 hours later) so he might be facing dialysis within the next day. He also is going through a slew of tests to determine what else is wrong. Please keep him in your thoughts and prayers this weekend. Thanks so much, Kim

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2009 08:24PM kimf wrote: Jenn, Good luck tomorrow. A 4.0 is amazing. With my lack of memory, I don't think I could pass a single exam, let alone score such wonderful grades for a semester. Proud of you! Luv2laff, my thyroid cancer was dx'd after breast cancer, but it existed prior to chemo. Unfortunately, it biopsied negative at first. The surgeon decided on the thyroidectomy from the start, cancer or not, due to the number of nodules (7) and the large goiter that I had. So after chemo, rads and a year of herceptin, I had the thyroid removed. At the follow up appt I found out it was cancer. Could have knocked me over with a feather. The type I had was a really benign type of cancer - nothing like IDC. No node involvement, no spread outside the tumor, all contained, couldn't have asked for a better cancer - ha! Hang in there...these treatments that we all have had kick cancer's butt, so think for the best.
Posts.Title: Hey girls kimf nguyenthang102

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 01:45PM kimf wrote: Bethie, So sorry you joined our ranks. I had a single mastectomy with a free tram reconstruction (tummy tuck). I had 3 small children (my baby was only 2) and the recovery required someone to be with me with the kids for weeks. I couldn't be happier with the cosmetic appearence of my new boob and my flat tummy. I do, however, regret not having both done. I have to have my other breast checked every six months (once by mammo and once by MRI). The fear is worse than anything. But, it would really be nice if I could get a bra that matched both breasts - none do. Clothes don't fit as well with one breast larger than the other or saggier than the other. It is a personal choice and I am not advising you, I'm just explaining my personal situation. Best of luck to you. Kick cancer's butt!

Posts.Content: kimf wrote: Just checking in to say hi. Been so busy lately that I haven't had time to check everyone's posts. I'm with you in spirit all the time my friends...even if I'm popping in infrequently. Saw my Endocrinologist yesterday. Everything is looking fine with my Synthroid & seems a complete cure to the thyroid cancer. I didn't expect anything suspicious. It was just a follow up. Sometimes sucks going 3 1/2 hours each way to New York for just a follow up...but I'll never regret going to Sloan for all this cancer crap. They've been the best to me. The boys started baseball this month, so things get busy really quickly for me. Both boys play on a different team and on a different level, so there is either practice or a game almost every night. We live at that darn ballpark until June! But, they love it and I love them, so we stick it out. Bella has her dance recital in June, too. OMG, the 3 & 4 year olds are just so precious up there doing their tap and ballet. I just well up thinking about it. She was only 2 when I was dx'd and I worried to death about not seeing her first recital...now I get to see her second and planning on seeing all the rest, too! Did the Elizabeth Edwards recurrence hit you guys as hard as it hit me? Damn disease. I hate it. Fill me in on what is going on! Kim Kimf Dx 12/16/2004, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 3, 15/23 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Hey girls kimf nguyenthang102

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2009 04:31AM kimf wrote: Hello to all the oldies out there. I realize newbies will look here, too, and you are more than welcome to jump into any and all subjects that float in here. Originally the hey girls was just to catch up with us old timers that were dx'd 3 - 5 years ago. We don't all frequent the boards any longer, so therefore, the post. Today I'm updating it with a hello to everyone! It has been way too long since we last all connected and I wanted to see how everyone is doing. Many of us are on facebook, which is awesome, but not everyone. I'll start...I'm doing GREAT! I don't see my Onc until January, but last I knew NED was still my best bud! I've had some depression issues with menopause, but switched meds and am hoping for the best. Menopause stinks but the hot flashes are so much better than before. I have gained weight, like most women seem to, and I don't like it, but am dealing and trying to be more active and eat better. The family is great. All are healthy. The flu has not hit our house yet, but is in the kids schools. I'm coming up on my 5 year cancerversary in December and am happy to pass that milestone!!!!!  My Onc uses the end of treatment as the 5 year mark, but I'm using my dx day. That's the day I became a survivor! How is everyone else? I know a few of us have passed on and others have progressed, but those of you still lurking in stage III, fill me in! Miss you all and pray for all of you here daily. Kimf

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2009 07:18AM kimf wrote: I'd march in there today and report that beeotch. That is disgusting that she treated you like that. I would insist on never having her again, ever. I'm so sorry you  had to go through that. I had 15+ nodes and never do scans. I was alarmed at first, too. Wanted to make sure everything worked etc. But my Onc does do tumor markers (blood tests) to check for fluctuations. Thankfully, she's right, I didn't need them so far. I have no symptoms, no changes in tumor markers and have been living without treatment for years. Some Onc's do scans regularly, others don't. I go to one of the top hospitals in the nation, hell, I didn't even have a port. They said it wasn't necessary until it was necessary. I got through 8 rounds of chemo and a year of herceptin on one arm. So...everyone is different. Another reason my Onc doesn't do scans is that if you have metastacized you will know it from pain, dizziness, shortness of breath etc. and you should be instructed to call if you ever have symptoms. You are in one of the scariest stages right now...finishing treatment. I think there is a thread on this board dedicated to that specifically so you can experience it with others at the same time. Look for it, it might help you feel better if others are being told the same stuff.  Good luck and feel good about yourself that you are getting ready to start rads. That's a great accomplishment! Kim

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 07:07AM kimf wrote: Rusty.....positive node(s) is not mets like everyone else said. I had 15 positive nodes and am stage IIIC as a result.  A 1 cm tumor with one positive lymph node puts you about stage 2A if I remember my staging correctly. Get your surgical path report back and discuss it in detail with your surgeon and Oncologist.  I think you will be relieved to hear the news they provide. Best wishes, Kim

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2007 04:10PM kimf wrote: Hip Hip Hooray! All went well today! The tech told me after the scan that the Radiologist saw no sign of metastatic cancer. I couldn't have been happier, but broke down in tears. What is up with that??? Geez, you'd think they gave me the opposite news. I'm elated, don't get me wrong, but so emotional. I guess I need to take more xanax. Mary-Anne, I agree, this headgame is the absolute pits! On a more positive note. I had the nicest conversation last night online with a dear old friend from high school that I haven't talked to in 8 years. He was a foreign exchange student for my junior & senior years and we became great friends. He has visited only once in 20+ years and after his last visit, we eventually lost touch. I "found" him again and was thrilled to hear how well he is doing and what he and his family are up to. It was really a highlight in a very stressful week. Just had to share. Thank you everyone for the pos vibes. I felt them! You guys are the best. Kim
Posts.Title: Hey girls kimf nguyenthang102

Our 25th reunion is next year and I've been checking to see if anyone is doing anything in preparation for it. I saw Jon posted and couldn't believe my luck that I could email him. It worked out perfect. Last night he web cammed himself so I could "see" him and everything. It was awesome. Kim
Posts.Title: Hey girls kimf nguyenthang102

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 09:15PM - edited Oct 2, 2007 09:15PM by kimf Thanks everyone. I agree, VV, I will be rocking those grandbabies one day! And Chelee, I don't like the new format either! Kari, I wish I could say the pain is gone, but its not. But I know what it isn't....bone mets...so I don't care as much that it hurts. Pete is trying to massage it out each night. I think it is stress. Now to unload again...my father in law has been really sick for like 2 months. He had pneumonia that didn't seem to go away, kept running a fever, bad cough, couldn't eat well due to mucous and reflux. Finally, he went back to the doc after weeks of this and two antibiotics not working and the doc had a CT scan done. They found a mass around his gall bladder, kidney & intestine. He had a second CT on Monday and an MRI today, tomorrow he sees an Oncologist for the results of these two tests. I know I've asked so much from you in the past...but I really need positive vibes and if you believe, prayers please. The Onc suggested that if the tumor was wrapped around these organs that there might not be anything to do. I cannot accept that - you know me....do anything and everything. I volunteered to go with him and my MIL tomorrow to the Onc, but they haven't called back so I don't know if they want me tagging along. My FIL is only 72 and has been working full time with our business year round forever. He's been so healthy. I'm in disbelief that this could be inoperable cancer. Well, I'll let you know as soon as I can what his status is, but thanks in advance for your vibes (and prayers!). Kim
Posts.Title: Hey girls kimf nguyenthang102

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2007 07:11AM - edited Oct 4, 2007 07:11AM by kimf Well, the Oncologist appt yesterday for my FIL didn't go so well. He has a large mass encompassing his gall bladder and bile duct, involving the liver as well, that is suffocating the common bile duct. The mass is most likely malignant, either originating in the gall bladder, but more likely a very rare cancer that starts in the bile duct called Cholangiocarcinoma. There will be a biopsy to confirm this. He has a fever and infection, so they want to treat him right away and admitted him into the hospital yesterday afternoon. The Resident Surgeon that I met last night said they will most likely put a stint into the bile duct to open the passageway to help the bile move. He is very jaundice right now and we know that his liver function isn't great. All his symptoms, weight loss, fatigue, jaundice, a sense of fullness...he has them all. The worst ...they found a spot on his liver that appears to be a metastasis. Ugh! I can't believe this. Keep the pos vibes and prayers coming. We need them! Thanks for your encouraging words. Kim

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2007 08:36PM kimf wrote: Thanks everyone. Hey Fumi! Cool that Donna came over and you two got to hang out. That's the best isn't it? Wish I was coming to visit!  Next time I'm in Japan I'll let you know, okay? My father in law is doing a bit better. He is still on dialysis, but there is improvement with his kidneys. He has stablized enough that the doctors are going to do dialysis tomorrow morning, then do the laproscopic biopsy afterward (not sure what time). It seems like a lot for him since he is really just back to eating and can barely stand he is so weak, but we have to find out what is causing all this so he can be treated. If it is cancer, then chemo can begin. If it isn't, then surgery seems the logical choice. Either way, I'm very worried since he is so weak, but he's a fighter. I can see where my dh gets his drive from that's for sure. I'm off to put the kiddies to bed. Take care, Kim
Posts.Title: Hey girls kimf nguyenthang102

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2008 08:07AM kimf wrote: Just popping in after a long absence. All is fine, just moving on with life. The kids keep me extremely busy, especially in the spring with all three playing little league. I go for my 6 mo Onc appt on 6/26. I feel all will be fine. I have my mammo that day, too. So, will hopefully have good news by the end of that day. As for the thyroid questions...sorry I'm so tardy in responding. There is just one correlation between thyroid and breast cancer that I know of...it is called "Cowden's disease" (sp?). There is a blood test that can be drawn to test for this through a genetic counselor. My results took 10 mos to get back and I was negative. My thyroid cancer was dx'd after my breast, but the nodules and goiter were there from the onset. They were two completely separate cancers. Just another way I try to be an overachiever, that's all. The thyroid cancer was very early, did not spread and with it being removed and one radioactive iodine treatment, I haven't worried about it since. Stage IIIC breast cancer worries me enough anyway!  Let me know how you both made out with your appointments. MaryAnne, so you finally did it? Had the recon and it didn't turn out they way you hoped. Did you do the expanders? How do they feel? Do you feel better? I'll be thinking of you and hope to hear that everything matches up this time. I haven't done the nipple yet, either. Its been over 3 years for me. Not sure I will or not. Heck, I still haven't had the lift and I have one hell of a saggy, breastfed three kids, breast going on there. What am I waiting for???? Take care everyone. Hope this finds all my stage III sisters feeling and doing well. Janis, you are in my thoughts today and everyday. Kim

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2009 03:25PM kimf wrote: Congrats Anna! My Onc says the same as everyone else...she feels all chemo/rads/herceptin worked unless you exhibit symptoms or tumor markers rise from visit to visit. The after treatment period was hard for many of us since we felt that we were actively fighting the disease. It is hard to just live again...but with time I became so happy to not have to travel to the hospital every week or two or three. Then it went from 3 month visits to 4 months then to 6 months and I am super happy not to have to go more frequently. You will get there. Believe in yourself and the tx you received! It really does work. Best wishes,

Its quite noticeable as it is super bright pinkso I don't want to ignore it either. I haven't changed detergents or soap or new bra or anything so ruled that stuff out. Any ideas????  Thanks. Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2008 08:55AM kimf wrote: Naomi, I had dense breasts, too. I was 39 - so pre-mammo age. My OB/gyn did an exam on me in Sept and found nothing. By Nov I was feeling my own lump. December got slammed with Stage IIIC IDC. I demanded an MRI prior to undergoing a lumpectomy b/c no one could answer my one question:  How do you know this is contained? Finally, they relented and found that the cancer was spreading all throughout my breast. As a result, I had the mastectomy & it probably saved my life. So...I'm a huge advocate for MRI's and have demanded that my sister obtain one. She has and thankfully she is clean, but her doc gave her no problems at all. She explained my situation and her Doc, being a breast cancer survivor herself, immediately suggested she have an MRI every year, just like I do. My daughter will as well when she enters her 20's. No other test at this point can show what the MRI does. The mammo doesn't even come close. Kim

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2008 05:00PM kimf wrote: Yes, papillary cancer, follicular variant is a thyroid cancer, not breast related in any way. It is as a  "benign" cancer as you can get for a malignancy. Not life threatening. Yes, hearing those ca words again floored me to say the least, but I delved into research and realized that it wasn't going to take my life.  Mindy, I'm sure you found the same thing? Hope this finds you feeling well.  Thank you for asking... I am dancing with NED as far as I know. I had a clear mammo last week, but no bloodwork results yet. I feel good and am living life. My Onc doesn't do regular scans, so we go forward as if NED will never go away! Take care, Kim

Posts.Title: Very bad report KariLynn roseg

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2008 01:20PM - edited Jun 28, 2008 01:23PM by kimf I was dx'd with stage IIIC IDC in 12/04. Had LB mast, recon, 15/23+ nodes. Did dd a/c, Taxol & a year of herceptin. During all this, we knew from the first CT scan that I had a large thyroid goiter and 7 nodules. I had the goiter biopsied and it was negative - the procedure was uncomfortable but not incredibly so - breast stuff is much more painful. Due to the number of nodules & size of the goiter, when I was nearly done the Herceptin, I had a total thyroidectomy. Turns out the goiter was cancerous. It was dx'd papillary ca, follicular variant. The treatment was having had the surgery and I did one radioactive iodine treatment. I take Synthroid every day and have no issues whatsoever. I was scared to death for a second ca dx, but the doctors all assure me that this thyroid cancer won't shorten my life by even one day. Sending pos vibes your way. Kim Oops, I just reread your posts above and see that the biopsy was benign! That's awesome. So glad for you.
Posts.Title: Thyroid Nodule? Msklapkin Honeybear

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2008 10:21PM kimf wrote: Mine was found with the routine CT scan that they usually do prior to chemo to look for mets. My endo could feel it externally when I swallowed, but I could not. It was 2 cm X 1.7 cm, so it wasn't too small. I was not hypo or hyper prior to having it removed. All my numbers were fine. I agree, have it checked by a pro. Kim

I had 15 pos nodes - stage IIIC....you can do this! I'm living proof it can be done. All my best, Kimf Dx 12/16/2004, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIIC, Grade 3, 15/23 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Stage 3 girlfriends you rock!  Linda,sorry about your blouse...lol! weeza I did 4 dd A/C, 4 dd Taxol with weekly herceptin, then herceptin every three weeks for a year. Also had 28 rads. This all followed the mast...of course. Best wishes to you all!

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2010 10:32AM kimf wrote: Thank you for the congrats! Annaanne, I totally remember you, too! I kept my scarves "just in case" but am always thinking positively that I will never need them! MaryAnne, thanks and good to see you with your boxing gloves still on! Hey Karen and Kerry!  anamcara - these girls are the best at giving support and loads of valuable information. I am by far not the only 5 year survivor at stage III and still ned. There are lots of us. and you will be one, too! Give it your all and fight the beast! You can do it! Kim
Posts.Title: Today is my 5 year cancerversary kimf maryannecb

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2010 07:03AM kimf wrote: You guys are so welcome, but I just wanted you to know it goes both ways. Us "long timers" are encouraged to live beyond cancer by seeing the fight you all are enduring. To be able to give hope and a bit of guidance is possibly a blessing that came out of this ordeal for me. You can survive and live long lives! We are doing it every day. Just remember to keep going and don't look back. Take care of yourself, your mind and body, and good things will happen to you too! (((Lauren))) hope you are well!
Posts.Title: Today is my 5 year cancerversary kimf maryannecb

Posts.Content: Sep 21, 2007 02:24PM kimf wrote: I'm broken hearted over this. Shelli, you reached out to me when I was newly diagnosed a few years ago. As a Mom to three young children, I felt a kinship with you immediately. I've admired how you faced this horrid disease with determination and grit. You are always going to be remembered here at bc.org by hundreds of women who have traveled with you on this journey. May you rest now in peace, no pain, no meds, no cancer....just eternal life. God bless your family and friends. Kimf
Posts.Title: Shelli is an angel geeta75 Sige

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2009 08:26AM kimf wrote: thisisme, Good luck with your Onc today.  I wanted to add that prior to going into surgery I was predicted to be stage II grade 2, no lymph involvement with 2.5 cm tumor. Post operatively, I was stage IIIC, grade 3, 3.5 cm tumor and 15 or 23 pos nodes, er/pr neg, her2 pos. I am over four years out and doing great. Do all the chemo they throw at you. Be as aggressive as you can. And you will kill the beast for good. Many of us have. I've never paid any attention to percentages, never discussed them with my Onc and don't ever plan to. I am not a statistic! Best wishes, Kim

Posts.Title: breast cancer didn't win today everyminute everyminute

Posts.Content: May 16, 2011 06:06AM kimf wrote: Thanks Karen, I did wake up this morning to much less redness and warmth so I think it must not be cellulitis. It wouldn't be getting better on it its own, right? It must have been something flukey yesterday and I worreied you all for no reason, sorry. Today it is pink but not bright and feels almost normal to the touch, so I think it is going to be fine. I'll keep an eye on it, but feel whatever was going on yesterday has passed....so weird tho, huh?
Posts.Title: hmmm, what's this? kimf karen1956

Posts.Content: May 16, 2011 02:06PM - edited May 16, 2011 02:06PM by kimf Binney, thank you. I have had LE and it has been treated by a well trained lymphedema therapist. I wrapped for 3 months, then wore a sleeve and glove for another 3 and had manual lymph drainage done several times a week with success. Thankfully I had a complete recovery and have been fine for 4 years. I can't say this isn't a new lymphedema, although that was in my lower arm/hand and this is my breast, but I will certainly pay close attention as I know the only reason I successfully got rid of my last swelling was because I dx'd it right away. Never thought of LE, so again, thank you!
Posts.Title: hmmm, what's this? kimf karen1956

Posts.Content: May 18, 2011 12:55PM kimf wrote: Thanks again everyone! I think I'm good to go. Looks great today and I just know if it was something to worry about, it wouldn't be so much better so quickly. So thank you all so much!
Posts.Title: hmmm, what's this? kimf karen1956

Posts.Content: May 17, 2011 09:46PM kimf wrote: hi dear friends! It's Pinkness is even less today, on my breast, and today no warmth. However, I think I see redness on my chest and possibly above the clavicle and slightly onto my neck. Pete says he thinks I'm always red there, I think he's got some wishful thinking. But no warmth there, or not much. This is so freaky. I haven't been in the sun or anything so I know it isn't sun related (and not there anyway!) I'll keep watching like a hawk. Thx again!
Posts.Title: hmmm, what's this? kimf karen1956

Posts.Content: Mar 23, 2010 02:23PM kimf wrote: Crossing fingers for negative results on your testing. Hoping for NED!
Posts.Title: How do I tell my family again sdavis jc3win

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2009 09:32AM kimf wrote: Me too, thanks for the thanks. Bugs did say it right, just paying it forward. Many of the ladies who paid it forward to us aren't on the boards any longer, but if they are watching or peeking in every now and again, I thank them from the bottom of my heart, too. They were to us what we are to you...living proof that you can survive surgery, chemo, rads, herceptin or whatever AI you take...and live many long meaningful cancer free years of life! Although none of us wanted to be in this club, I couldn't have asked for a better group of women to be bonded with in it.
Posts.Title: Thank you to those who come back and give us hope! everyminute helena67
